chapter.title: Common Idioms For All Resources
chapter.para: Resources are represented by XML documents e.g.
The following attributes are common to all resource descriptions:

row.entry: An opaque server-generated identifier for the resource which is guaranteed to be unique across all resources in this Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization Manager instance
The canonical location of the resource as an absolute path

chapter.para: The following elements are common to all resource descriptions:

row.entry: A user-supplied human readable name for the resource which also must be unique across all resources
A free-form user-supplied human readable description of the resource

row.entry: These elements must be included in the client-provided representation of a resource on creation, but are not mandatory for an update of a resource.

These elements cannot have their value changed when updating a resource. They may only be included in a client-provided representation on update if their values have not been altered. Otherwise they should be omitted from an update action.
These elements are read-only. Values for read-only elements are not created or modified.

section.title: Listing Resources
section.para: A listing of the resources in a collection is obtained by issuing a GET request on the collection URI obtained from the entry point.
section.screen:
GET /rhevm-api/resources/ HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml
HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Type: application/xml
<resources> <resource id="{id}" href="/rhevm-api/resources/{id}"> <name>foo</name> <description>The Foo Resource</description> ... </resource> <resource ...> ... </resource> </resources>

section.title: Listing Resource Sub-Collections
section.para: A request for resources also allows for extended sub-collection listings using the detail parameter in the Accept header.
This includes multiple sub-collection requests using either seperated detail parameters:
section.screen: GET /rhevm-api/resources/ HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml; detail=subcollection1; detail=subcollection2
section.para: Or one detail parameter that seperates the sub-collection with the + operator:
The API only supports the statistics sub-collection listings for vms and hosts.

section.title: Querying a Collection
section.para: A collection is queried using a GET request on an appropriate "collection/search" URI template, instantiated with a query constraint expressed in the Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization Manager query language. Only those resources in the collection satisfying the constraint will be returned.
section.screen:
GET /rhevm-api/resources?search={query} HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml
HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Type: application/xml
<resources> <resource id="{id}" href="/rhevm-api/resources/{id}"> ... </resource> ... </resources>
section.para: More information about queries is found in .

section.title: Retrieving a Resource
section.para: The state of a resource can be retrieved using GET request on a URI obtained from the listing above.
section.screen:
GET /rhevm-api/resources/{id} HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml
HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Type: application/xml
<resource id="{id}" href="/rhevm-api/resources/{id}"> ... </resource>

section.title: Creating a Resource
section.para: A new resource may be created by issueing a POST request to collection URI containing a representation of the new resource.

Each resource type has its own specific required properties which the client must supply when creating a new resource. Refer to the indiviual resource type documentation for more details. If a required property is absent, the creation will fail with a Fault representation indicating the missing elements.
section.screen:
POST /rhevm-api/resources HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml Content-Type: application/xml
<resource> <name>foo</name> </resource>
HTTP/1.1 201 Created Location: http://{host}/resources/1234-abcd-6789-ef00 Content-Type: application/xml
<resource id="1234-abcd-6789-ef00" href="/rhevm-api/resources/1234-abcd-6789-ef00"> <name>foo</name> ... </resource>
section.para: The Location header in the response gives the URI from which the resource may be queried. The response body can contain a complete representation, partial representation or no representation of the resource, so clients should rely only on fetching the representation via the URI in the response header.

section.title: Updating a Resource
section.para: Some resource properties can be modified by PUTing an updated description to the resource URI. Details on which properties are modifiable can be found in the individual resource type documentation.
section.screen:
PUT /rhevm-api/resources/{id} HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml Content-Type: application/xml
<resource> <name>foo</name> </resource>
HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Type: application/xml
<resource id="..." href="/rhevm-api/..."> <name>foo</name> ... </resource>
section.para: Again, the server may or may not return the updated resource description in the response body.

If an attempt is made to modify a strictly immutable resource property, this is reported as 409 Conflict error with a Fault representation in the response body. Other non-modifiable properties specified in the request entity-body may be silently ignored.

section.title: Deleting a Resource
section.para: A resource is deleted by issuing a DELETE request to its URI.

section.title: Actions
section.para: Each resource description includes a list of action links describing operations which may be invoked on the resource.

An action may be invoked by POSTing to the supplied URI. The body of the POST must contain an Action representation encapsulating common and/or task-specific parameters. Common action parameters include:
async true if the server should respond immediately with 202 Accepted and an action representation containing a href link which may be polled for completion.
grace_period a grace period in milliseconds, which must expire before the action is initiated.
Individual actions and their parameters are documented in the individual resource type's documentation. Some parameters are mandatory for specific actions, in which case their absence is indicated with a Fault response.
When the action is initiated asychronously, the immediate 202 Accepted response provides a link that may be polled to monitor the status of the task:
section.screen:
POST /rhevm-api/resources/{id}/{verb} HTTP/1.1 Content-Type: application/xml Accept: application/xml
<action> <async>true</async> </action>
HTTP/1.1 202 Accepted Content-Type: application/xml
<action id="{action_id}" href="/rhevm-api/resources/{id}/{verb}/{action_id}"> <async>true</async> ... <action>
section.para:
A subsequent GET on the action URI provides an indication of the status of the asynchronous task:
PENDING task has not yet started.
IN_PROGRESS task is in flight.
COMPLETE task has completed successfully.
FAILED task has failed, in which case the returned Action representation would contain a Fault describing the failure.
Once the task has completed, the Action is retained for an indeterminate period. Once this has expired, subsequent GETs are 301 Moved Permanently redirected back to the target resource.
section.screen:
GET /rhevm-api/resources/{id}/{verb}/{action_id} HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml
HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Type: application/xml
<action id="{action_id}" href="/rhevm-api/resources/{id}/{verb}/{action_id}"> <status>{PENDING|IN_PROGRESS|COMPLETE|FAILED}</status> <link rel="parent" href="/rhevm-api/resources/{id}"/> <link rel="replay" href="/rhevm-api/resources/{id}/{verb}"/> <action>
section.para:
An action description may also include some links which are identified by their rel attribute:
parent A link back to the resource which this action was invoked upon
replay A link back to the original action URI. POSTing to this URI will causing the action to be re-initiated

section.title: Permissions
section.para: Each resource contains a permissions sub-collection. Each permission contains a user, an assigned role and the specified resource. For example:
section.screen:
GET /rhevm-api/resources/{id}/permissions HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml
HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Type: application/xml
<permissions> <permission id="{permission-id}" href="/rhevm-api/resources/{id}/permissions/{permission-id}"> <role id="{role-id}" href="/rhevm-api/roles/{role-id}"/> <user id="{role-id}" href="/rhevm-api/users/{role-id}"/> <resource id="{id}" href="/rhevm-api/resources/{id}"/> </permission> ... </permissions>
section.para: A resource acquires a new permission when POSTed to its permissions sub-collection. Each new permission requires a role and a user:
section.screen:
POST /rhevm-api/resources/{id}/permissions HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml
<permission"> <role id="{role-id}"/> <user id="{role-id}"/> </permission>
HTTP/1.1 201 Created Content-Type: application/xml
<permission id="{permission-id}" href="/rhevm-api/resources/{id}/permissions/{permission-id}"> <role id="{role-id}" href="/rhevm-api/roles/{role-id}"/> <user id="{role-id}" href="/rhevm-api/users/{role-id}"/> <resource id="{id}" href="/rhevm-api/resources/{id}"/> </permission>

section.title: Handling Errors
section.para: Some errors require further explanation beyond that provided by a standard HTTP status code. For example, an unsuccessful resource state update or action is reported with a Fault representation in the response entity-body. The fault contains reason and detail strings, which may be localized for the client's locale as specified via the Accept-Language HTTP header. Clients initiating a request which may fail in this way must be prepared to unmarshal either a Fault or the expected resource representation, depending on the response status code. Such cases are clearly indicated in the individual resource documentation.
section.screen:
PUT /rhevm-api/resources/{id} HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml Content-Type: application/xml
<resource> <id>bar</id> </resource>
HTTP/1.1 409 Conflict Content-Type: application/xml
<fault> <reason>Broken immutability constraint</reason> <detail>Attempt to set immutable field: id</detail> </fault>
